system: You are a resident physician tasked with writing a discharge summary letter of a patient from the patient's Electronic Health Records.
user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

Dear ___,

This letter summarizes your recent hospital stay and outlines the plans for your continued care following your discharge. You were admitted to our facility on March 10, 2024, following a fall and subsequent loss of consciousness. Upon admission, your Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was recorded at 11, and slurring of speech was noted.

On March 11, 2024, a CT scan was performed which confirmed the presence of a hemorrhagic stroke in the right hemisphere of your brain. This identification led to a diagnosis of intracerebral hemorrhage, unspecified, coded as I61.9. To manage cerebral edema, mannitol was administered at a dose of 0.25 g/kg every six hours. Furthermore, antihypertensive medications were given as per blood pressure requirements.

Laboratory assessments conducted on March 11 showed a slightly low hemoglobin count and elevated white blood cells. The coagulation profile indicated an elevated INR which suggested a prolonged bleeding time.

Throughout your stay, evaluations on March 11, 2024, indicated right-sided weakness alongside persistent slurred speech. Despite these interventions, as of March 12, your condition remained critical with ongoing symptoms and no significant change in your neurological status. Due to the presence of agitation and confusion, safety measures were implemented to prevent further falls.

During a discussion involving your family, considerations regarding your prognosis and ongoing care needs were addressed. At that time, your medical team deemed that you required continued monitoring and were not yet safe for discharge.

Please ensure that you adhere to your follow-up care appointments post-discharge. It is important to continue the prescribed medical regimen and consult with your healthcare provider for any concerns or if new symptoms arise.

We kindly ask that you schedule a follow-up consultation with your primary care physician or neurologist soon after discharge to reassess your condition and make any necessary adjustments to your treatment plan.

We are here to assist you throughout your recovery. Should you have any questions regarding your care or need additional information, do not hesitate to contact us.

Wishing you a safe and speedy recovery.

Yours sincerely,

Dr. ___
